DOC.HEAD: Police Fire Tear Gas After Refugees Refuse To Cooperate In Weapons Search
Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE number of injured, arrests; picks up xth pvs, `Although officials...'
DOC.TEXT: Police in riot gear fired tear gas into a detention center today to quell unrest by Vietnamese boat people who refused to cooperate in a search for homemade weapons. Officials said 40 people were injured. Police found more than 700 weapons in the early afternoon search and arrested 27 Vietnamese. The violence came a day after fights broke out between two groups of Vietnamese in a second center. One person was killed and 10 injured in the clashes. Vietnamese at the Chi Ma Wan center threw stones and set fire to blankets after security forces arrived for the weapons search, government spokesman Timothy Li said. Television showed police equipped with helmets and shields firing tear gas, and smoke from fires could be seen rising above the center. Police said 14 Vietnamese and 26 guards and policemen were injured in the camp on outlying Lantau Island. ``The boat people, in order to make the operation more difficult, pushed their women and children to the front,'' Security Secretary M. Geoffrey Barnes said in a government statement. Although officials refused to say how many police were used in the operation, government-funded radio put the number at about 300. Five hours of counseling by staff of the U.N. High Commissioner of Refugees and voluntary agencies failed to persuade the Vietnamese to cooperate, the government statement said. The radio reported that the resistance may have been prompted by reports that some of the Chi Ma Wan inmates may be in the next group of boat people forced to return to their impoverished homeland. That fatality occurred at the Shek Kong Detention Center late Thursday when two fights broke out between two rival groups of Vietnamese boat people armed with homemade weapons, police said. No one was arrested at Shek Kong but police found homemade weapons such as swords and lances after the battles. Police say five people have died this year in factional fighting in the crowded, squalid camps housing the boat people in this British colony. The residents of both camps are among about 44,000 boat people who have sailed into Hong Kong since mid-June 1988 and are considered illegal immigrants unless they can prove they fled persecution. Hong Kong forcibly repatriated 51 boat people to Hanoi against their will earlier this month and reports have said another group will be forced home next month. Meanwhile, the eighth batch of boat people to volunteer to return to their Communist homeland flew back to Hanoi today. The 72 men, 29 women and 10 children took a chartered flight. Their departure brings to 874 the number of Vietnamese who have returned home voluntarily since March.
